awd_titl_txt: SHF: Medium: Closing Multiphysics Analysis Gaps in System Design
awd_abstract_narration:
Design tools and methods for electronic components need to ensure that they are low-cost, low-energy, last longer, deliver better performance, and operate correctly across a diverse range of conditions. To guarantee this, engineers need analysis tools that understand mechanical shock, temperature, aging and in addition to electrical phenomena - in short, many different "physics" that are all wrapped up into a single analysis question.  The analysis must also span time scales from nanoseconds to years, and spatial scales from nanometers to centimeters. Such tools do not exist today. This project will develop the "multiphysics" analysis methods that aims to address such questions for future electronic system designers.  Researchers will bring together techniques from chip design, thermal and reliability analysis, mechanical simulation and other domains learning each other?s fields of expertise, and creating new analysis tools that will be used in both industry and teaching contexts. The outreach aspects of the project involve training undergraduate and graduate students for the electronic design automation industry.

The project will have three main technical goals.  The first goal is to come up with fast algorithms to simulate and predict the physics of heat propagation, mechanical stress, and electrical signaling in extremely complex structures.  The second goal is to enable computer codes to span multiple scales in space and in time. This will allow system design tools to correctly analyze propagation of electrical signals through nanoscale devices as the larger system is subjected to heating or mechanical shocks occurring at much longer time scales.  The third goal is to develop new ways of efficiently understanding "multiphysics", e.g., the interaction between electrical, thermal and mechanical, along with temporal phenomena, when analyzing an electronic system.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: DES AUTO FOR MICRO & NANO SYST
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In advanced technologies, microelectronics product designs face increasingly severe challenges of power density, thermomechanical stress and reliability. This magnifies the costs and impacts of guardbanding and overdesign. A system with a wide range of operating conditions will require efficient and accurate multiphysics signoff analysis during the design process. The results of this project help close the multiphysics analysis gap through novel multiscale, multiphysics analysis flows that comprehend interactions between physical mechanisms (power, thermal, stress, current) along with design performance and reliability. These methods contribute to enhanced reliability and robustness of devices. 

Intellectual Merit. The project entailed three main research thrusts: (1) thermomechanical simulation, (2) circuit-level simulation, and (3) integrated system-level design analysis and optimization methodology. 

In the thermomechanical simulation thrust, research on stress simulation enabled a multiscale framework to simulate crack propagation with given time-varying thermal maps. The framework accurately captures discontinuities across crack surfaces, high stress concentrations near crack tips, and the temperature influence on material displacement and stress. Research also developed a framework to simulate the thermal cycling of electronic packages to study potential failure in an electronic package. A new drop test simulation method enables study of the impact of vertical acceleration on reliability of electronic systems. Also, an efficient computational approach was developed for modeling of electronic packages subjected to long-term thermal cycling. This was supported by new techniques for numerical modeling and for learning from training datasets. Efficiency and accuracy of these research products have been verified for the thermal fatigue modeling of electronic packages.

In the circuit-level simulation thrust, we conceived new numerical techniques and methodologies to connect the device, stress, and circuit performance with greater accuracy and scalability. Achievements include time-domain simulation for large power distribution systems at huge scale, based on matrix exponential and vector product. A new, stable algorithm for computing the matrix exponential in the time domain simulation of large-scale power delivery networks was developed. A new Arnoldi algorithm, called AWESOME, was confirmed with both theoretical proofs and experiments. Notably, testing on a group of system-level power delivery networks showed that matrix exponential based algorithms could achieve high efficiency and accuracy. 

In the integrated system-level design analysis and optimization methodology thrust, we enabled new workload- and multiphysics-aware simulation methods, and cross-layer optimization spanning logical, physical and circuit layers of inter-chiplet networks in 2.5D systems. We also enabled co-optimization across three layers of design (logical, physical and circuit) to achieve an energy-efficient interchiplet network to deliver required system performance along with energy and thermal feasibility. Further, we developed learning-based models to predict both pre-layout and post-layout die bump inductance, which is a critical element of package power delivery network quality assessment.

To prevent wasteful overdesign and pessimism in PDN design, we developed routability-aware PDN synthesis methodologies and a "pathfinding" methodology for emerging 3D integration contexts. To cure the large turnaround time of today?s synthesis-analysis loop, we developed machine-learning based IR drop prediction methods. Last, the PROBE3.0 framework enables systematic, principled evaluation of routability, density, power and performance (PPAC) figures of merit across the "full stack of enablement" (technology, design, and design methodology) at an early stage of technology development.


Broader Impacts. Broad impacts were achieved along two main directions: (1) training and development; and (2) outreach and dissemination.  Toward training and development, over the life of the award three high school students, two undergraduate students, 10 Ph.D. students, and three postdoctoral researchers have been exposed to the latest industrial problems and trained with state of the art VLSI implementation tools, technologies and mechanical analysis theories. They have developed concrete coding and analysis skills in related fields.  Toward outreach and dissemination, project participants have interacted extensively with industrial and other researchers. Close interaction with mentors in Qualcomm Technologies, Qualcomm Research and ANSYS have given us access to real-world motivations and problem formulations, and feedback on our studies. Multiple project outcomes (e.g., the PROBE3.0 pathfinding software package) have been permissively open-sourced.

 


 

 


Last Modified: 04/04/2023
Modified by: Andrew B Kahng
